name: Keep the fire burning
description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

key_work.title: Yanmeeyarr
key_work.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
key_work.material_description:
Mixed media. Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
key_work.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Song is used to retell history in Looky Looky Here Comes Cooky, directed by Steven McGregor and presented and co-written by Steven Oliver. Six musicians perform original songs that challenge the dominant dialogue surrounding the legacy of Captain Cook’s HMB Endeavour, 250 years on.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Servant or Slave follows five Aboriginal women who were stolen from their families and forced into domestic labour, interrogating government policy in the removal of children, the control of wages, and the abuse endured by many to expose an unspoken part of Australia’s history.

start.title: Yanmeeyarr
start.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
start.material_description:
Mixed media. Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
start.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: VIDEO WORKS
end.brief_description: VIDEO WORKS is an immersive composite of three major video installations by Sydney-based Kudjala/Gangalu artist Daniel Boyd that map the gallery walls with Boyd’s infinite cosmos of dynamic compositions and prismatic colour.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Daniel Boyd uses ‘lenses’ to create small portals for colour and imagery to shine through. Dark negative space creates contrast, raising questions around how we perceive dark vs light. VIDEO WORKS creates an infinite cosmos from these, where colour and form create a moving image.

start.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
start.material_description: Video loop, artist and Michael Bonner (performer)
start.brief_description: Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

constellations_primary.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_primary.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: The Promise
end.brief_description: Julie Gough’s The Promise (2011) uses light and shadow to illuminate the mistreatment of First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Julie Gough uses shadows in The Promise, which like Baker’s work encourages audiences to reconsider the history they’ve been told. Using a chair and a shadow casting LED, Gough shines a light on Australia’s violent treatment of First Peoples.

start.title: The Promise
start.brief_description: Julie Gough’s The Promise (2011) uses light and shadow to illuminate the mistreatment of First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: First Australians
end.brief_description: First Australians is a historical documentary series produced by Blackfella Films over the course of six years, and first aired in October 2008.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Rachel Perkins
constellations_other.description: The moving image has helped tell First Peoples stories through documentary, films and TV shows, with acclaimed director, producer and screenwriter Rachel Perkins contributing significantly to these stories.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: First Australians tells the history of colonisation in Australia from the perspective of First Peoples. Rachel Perkins’ series reveals the violence and the genocidal tactics of the colonial government during first contact and the ongoing effects into the current day.

start.title: First Australians
start.brief_description: First Australians is a historical documentary series produced by Blackfella Films over the course of six years, and first aired in October 2008.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Rachel Perkins
constellations_other.description: The moving image has helped tell First Peoples stories through documentary, films and TV shows, with acclaimed director, producer and screenwriter Rachel Perkins contributing significantly to these stories.

end.title: Out of the Sea Like a Cloud

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Truth-telling is at the core of Fiona Foley’s Out of the Sea Like a Cloud, which looks back to first contact of the Badtjala people with colonisers; using the oldest documented song to tell their story of the sighting of the 1770 Endeavour ship’s voyage.

start.title: VIDEO WORKS
start.brief_description: VIDEO WORKS is an immersive composite of three major video installations by Sydney-based Kudjala/Gangalu artist Daniel Boyd that map the gallery walls with Boyd’s infinite cosmos of dynamic compositions and prismatic colour.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
end.material_description: Video loop, artist and Michael Bonner (performer)
end.brief_description: Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

constellations_primary.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_primary.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Ali Gumilya Baker uses darkness in down among the wild men / colonial imagination. Not just in a literal sense by using shadows, but thematically by looking at the darkness of Australia’s past by questioning and redressing how history has been told.

start.title: The Silenced
start.credit_line:
Julie Gough

Single-channel video, sound, 6:18 mins.

ACMI Collection

Edited by Jemma Rae
start.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
start.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Larissa Behrendt’s documentary film exposes the extreme rates that First Nations children are currently being taken from their families. Following the 2008 apology for the Stolen Generations administered by Kevin Rudd, the rate of Indigenous children being removed has increased.

start.title: The Promise
start.brief_description: Julie Gough’s The Promise (2011) uses light and shadow to illuminate the mistreatment of First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

end.title: The Silenced
end.credit_line:
Julie Gough

Single-channel video, sound, 6:18 mins.

ACMI Collection

Edited by Jemma Rae
end.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
end.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

links.description: Gough’s The Silenced assesses colonialism and its impact on First Peoples by focusing on the Aboriginal children who were stolen from their families in the 1800s and forced to work. The records of these children were often buried and hidden from sight.
